questions.text: What are the sequential steps in rigour mortis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rigor mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.

Order of Appearance:

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes

Rigor mortis

Rigor mortis (RM), or cadaveric rigidity, refers to the stiffening of muscles after death, resulting from biochemical changes within muscle cells due to ATP depletion.

Progression of Rigor Mortis:

The progression of rigor mortis can be divided into three main phases.

Rules of Progression

1. Nysten's Rule

Rigour mortis progresses in a specific sequence, starting from the myocardium to the eyelids, neck, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs.

Order of Appearance:

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles→ Neck → Lower jaw→ Muscles of face → Muscles of chest→ Upper limbs → Abdomen→ Lower limbs→ Fingers and toes

Order of Disappearance:

Fingers and toes → Lower limbs → Abdomen → Upper limbs → Muscles of chest → Muscles of face → Lower jaw → Neck → Eyelid muscles → Myocardium

2. Shapiro's RuleRigor mortis is a biochemical process that occurs simultaneously across all muscles, with visibility depending on muscle bulk.

3. Rule of 12

Onset occurs at 60 minutes, peaks at 12 hours, remains for another 12 hours, and resolves completely thereafter.

questions.text: In cases involving sexual assault, how is the testimony of a female victim typically recorded in court?
questions.solution:
Under Section 327 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) in India, sexual assault cases mandate in-camera proceedings to ensure confidentiality and protect the victim from public scrutiny.

Explanation for other options:

Open court proceedings (Option A): In sexual assault cases, the privacy of the victim is prioritised, and open court proceedings are avoided to protect the victim's identity and dignity.

Closed court proceedings (Option B): While closed court proceedings ensure limited public access, they are not as specific or protective as hearings conducted on camera.

Hearing in a different location (Option C): While certain situations might necessitate a different location for the hearing, it is not the standard protocol for recording evidence in sexual assault cases.

Reference

questions.text: An individual found near a railway track presents with dry skin, dilated dry pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium. Which of the following substances is the most likely cause of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Datura poisoning is characterised by anticholinergic symptoms such as dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), dry mouth, tachycardia, slurred speech, hallucinations, confusion, and altered sensorium.

  • The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds.
  • Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.
  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centres of the brain and then activates the motor centres. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centres in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
  • Dryness of the mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
  • Photophobia + Diplopia
  • Agitation and restlessness
  • Delirium
  • Urinary retention
  • Dry and hot skin
  • Exfoliation of the skin may occur

  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

Explanation for other options:

Morphine (Option A): Morphine poisoning typically causes pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and sedation. Dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic features.

Cannabis (Option B): Cannabis intoxication may cause euphoria, altered sensorium, conjunctival injection (red eyes) and increased appetite, but does not present with dry skin, dilated pupils, or the anticholinergic toxidrome seen in this case.

Alcohol (Option D): Alcohol intoxication commonly causes slurred speech and altered sensorium, but it does not result in dry skin or dilated pupils.

questions.text: A child is born eight months following the death of the presumed father. Despite doubts about paternity from the paternal grandparents, DNA testing confirms the child is biologically related to their son. What term best describes this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A posthumous child is one born after the death of the father. The scenario described fits this definition.

Explanation for other options:

Suppositious child (Option A):

  • This term describes a fictitious child where a woman may pretend to be pregnant and later present a living child as her own.
  • This can involve substituting one child for another or claiming a child after an abortion, typically for financial gain or to claim property.
  • In this case, there is no indication of deception or substitution, so this option does not apply.

Fabricated child (Option B): Fabricated or induced illness (FII) is an uncommon type of child abuse where a parent or caregiver intentionally exaggerates or causes symptoms of illness in a child.

Illegitimate child (Option D):

Also known as a bastard, this describes a child born out of lawful wedlock or not within a competent time after the dissolution of marriage.

  • In this scenario, the child is born to a woman who was married, making this option incorrect.
  • Certain conditions can render a child illegitimate, including if the alleged father is under the age of puberty, physically incapable of fathering children, not sexually accessible to the mother at the time of conception, or has blood group incompatibility.
  • Legitimate Child: A child born during a lawful marriage or within 280 days after the marriage has been dissolved by divorce or death of the husband, as long as the mother remains unmarried.

Fabricated or induced illness: From "Munchausen by proxy" to child and family-oriented action - PubMed

questions.text: A rectal swab is taken from a child brought by a police officer with suspicion of sexual harassment and the finding of the test is shown below. What is the test  performed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.

  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.


 

Explanation for other options:

Teichmann test (Option A): This test detects haemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

Takayama test (Option C): Similar to the Teichmann test, the Takayama test is used for haemoglobin detection.

Florence Test (Option D): This test detects choline and produces different crystal formations (dark brown rhombic crystals).

questions.text: The dead body shows characteristic findings (as depicted in the image). What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smothering involves obstruction of the nose and mouth, usually without specific injuries to the neck. Bruises or abrasions on the face may be present, but are not localised to the neck.

Explanation for other options:

Hanging (Option A): Hanging typically shows an oblique, non-continuous ligature mark on the neck, located higher up (above the thyroid cartilage). There is usually no evidence of external injuries like bruises or fingernail marks around the neck.

Throttling (Option B): Throttling refers to manual strangulation. The findings often include bruising, abrasions, or fingernail marks on the neck, which are characteristic of a physical struggle. There may also be petechial haemorrhages in the eyes and other areas due to venous congestion.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about adipocere formation is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Adipocere is a waxy substance formed postmortem due to the hydrolysis and hydrogenation of fat tissues in the body. This process is called saponification.

Adipocere (Saponification or Grave Wax):

  • Formation of fatty acid soap in warm, humid climates or when submerged in water. (Option B, C ruled out)
  • Process: Fatty acids undergo hydrolysis and hydrogenation, forming a waxy substance.
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Preserves body tissues for easier identification.
    • Formation takes 3 days to 3 months. (Option D ruled out)
  • Types of adipocere:
    • Fresh: Soft, moist, white, greasy.
    • Old: Dry, hard, brittle, yellow.
  • Absent fetus less than 7 months.

Key takeaways:

Mummification

  • Occurs in dry, hot climates due to dehydration, preserving the body.
  • Loss of 60-70% body weight over 3-12 months.
  • Intra-uterine death can also result in mummification.
  • Chronic arsenic or antimony poisoning favours the process of mummification
  • Medical Importance:
    • Describes the climate at the time of death.
    • Helps in the determination of time since death (TSD) and easy identification.

questions.text: In the event of a death resulting from a road traffic accident, which authority is responsible for requesting an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation

In cases of Road Traffic Accidents (RTA), the police are responsible for ordering the autopsy. This is part of their duty to investigate the circumstances of the death and to ensure that the legal procedures are followed correctly. (Option A, C and D ruled out)

  • If the cause of death is unclear or if required for legal reasons, the police will request an autopsy to establish the cause of death.

key takeaway:

In India, medico-legal post-mortem examinations are carried out upon receiving a written order from a police officer, as authorised under Section 174 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC), or from a magistrate under Section 176 of the CrPC, depending on the case's circumstances.

Reference:
